categories.title: Hyperfy Platform Development and Community Updates

content.text: The Hyperfy development team and community have been actively discussing and implementing a range of technical enhancements, UX improvements, and feature requests across the platform. A major focus has been on the new Gizmo tool, which introduces rotation snapping, local/world space toggling (via the 'T' key), and grid snapping. Future plans include adding scale manipulation. Community feedback on Gizmo has been positive, with users noting its intuitive design and ease of use.

Material and mesh handling improvements were also discussed. Developers are working on supporting base color and emission field changes, and removing limitations tied to MeshStandardMaterial to allow broader material compatibility. Linked vs. unlinked meshes were clarified, with unlinking recommended for unique material changes. Transparency and collision rendering issues were also addressed, with guidance on flipping normals in Blender and tagging meshes as colliders.

App architecture and communication protocols were clarified. Nodes moved to world space remain tied to their app lifecycle, and JSON-only messaging is encouraged to avoid unpredictable behavior. Reparenting objects across apps is discouraged. Instanced apps can be made unique for independent material changes, and cloning with children requires the use of clone(true).

User experience in build mode is being enhanced with features like toggling between player and camera modes, hiding the player during building, and a 'zoom to' feature in the app outliner. A floating camera mode and UI simplification are also planned. Performance optimizations include using LOD nodes for UI rendering control and adding node.onMount/onUnmount callbacks.

In the marketplace, an isometric layout for asset collections is being implemented, allowing each item (as a .hyp file) to be individually dragged and dropped. This feature is under development by szjanko, with early testing access offered. Documentation and guides for this functionality are planned.

Community members also discussed lightmap testing for shooter arenas, with positive feedback on visual quality. External tools like poly.cam for AI texture generation were shared, though limitations such as subscription models were noted. These tools may influence future development decisions.

In the MMO game context, users suggested integrating wallet-based login and NFT storage. While no implementation was confirmed, the ideas were acknowledged as potential feature requests. This reflects growing interest in Web3 integration within the Hyperfy ecosystem.

Community engagement remains strong, with users helping each other troubleshoot issues, share tools, and provide feedback. Tutorial sessions and content creation efforts are ongoing, though some scheduling issues were noted. Suggestions were made to improve communication and documentation around these events.
The current price of SOL (Solana) is $124.52, which may be relevant for users interested in blockchain-based features or NFT integration within Hyperfy.
